summary: On July 27, 2015, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York entered a final judgment against New York City Police Department officer Daniel Pantaleo in a civil rights case brought by the New York Civil Liberties Union.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Manhattan on July 17, 2014 and unsealed on July 24, 2014, the court found that, in violation of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and that the SEC was entitled to an exemption from disclosure provided for by the federal securities laws.  The court also ruled that, without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, the SEC had the right to determine whether the records constituted "personnel records" exempt from disclosure.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for New York today announced that it filed criminal charges and issued an order freezing the assets of the SEC and other emergency relief, including asset freezes, temporary restraining orders, and officer-to-officer transfers. The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted in the Office of Inspector General's Analysis and Detection Center (OIGC), with the assistance of the Division of Justice's Office of Criminal Investigations. The litigation will be led by Ms. Schlesinger and supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay. The case is being supervised by Kelly L. Gibson, Chief of the OIGC's Analysis Section. The court will determine the amount of disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties to be determined by the court upon motion by the SEC.  For further information, see Matter of Capital Newspapers Div. v. New York State Department of Corrections, No. 10-cv-01221. The Commission on Civil Rights has issued an Order suspending the issuance, purchase, offer, and sale of any emergency relief that may be obtained from the SEC, including from the Department of Justice, the FBI, the Internal Revenue Service, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the New Jersey Department of Banking and Securities and Investments. The Court will determine whether to issue an order permanently enjoining the SEC from future violations of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(a) of The Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act"), ordering the SEC to comply with the Commission's order, and ordering the issuance of an order appointing an independent receiver to determine the appropriate amount of relief. The Division of Enforcement's investigation was conducted by Michael J. Pyszka and was supervised by Jennifer C. Barry of the Public Finance Abuse Unit, with assistance from Joseph G.
